thread.title: No. 23 Hornets look to improve to 5-0 vs. Lindenwood
thread.title_full: No. 23 Hornets look to improve to 5-0 vs. Lindenwood

author: Rick Peterson Jr.
title: No. 23 Hornets look to improve to 5-0 vs. Lindenwood
text:
No. 23 Hornets look to improve to 5-0 vs. Lindenwood Lions enter on three-game losing streak Posted: October 1, 2015 - 3:04pm MIAA GAMES SATURDAY 
Northwest Missouri at Northeastern State, 1 p.m. 
Missouri Southern at Central Missouri, 1:30 p.m. 
Missouri Western at Pittsburg State, 2 p.m. 
Nebraska-Kearney at Central Oklahoma, 2 p.m. 
Emporia State at Lindenwood, 2:37 p.m. 
Washburn at Fort Hays State, 7 p.m. By Rick Peterson Jr. richard.peterson@cjonline.com 
Since opening the season with an inspiring win over Washburn, Lindenwood has struggled to gain any traction, dropping three straight games. 
As Emporia State coach Garin Higgins sees it, Lindenwood’s recent struggles are more indicative of the rugged MIAA than anything else. 
“In the MIAA, you could be a very good football team and be 1-3, just because of the league that you play in,” Higgins said. “I look at the conference standings, and there are a lot of teams that don’t have the best records and are very good football teams, and Lindenwood is one of those.” 
The No. 23-ranked Hornets will look to improve to 5-0 when they play Lindenwood at 2 p.m. Saturday in St. Charles, Mo. The matchup is the MIAA’s Television Game of the Week and is available on Cox Channel Kansas. 
Though Lindenwood’s three losses have been by at least 20 points, the Lions bring their fair share of concerns, Higgins said. 
“I think they have a very talented quarterback (Jesse Scroggins),” Higgins said. “They’ve got some skilled athletes, and they play fast on defense.” 
Lindenwood linebacker Connor Harris leads the nation in tackles with 60. 
The Lions will have their hands full trying to slow down Emporia State’s offense, which leads the conference in total offense (533.8 yards per game) and points scored (44 per game). 
ESU quarterback Brent Wilson leads the MIAA with 1,377 yards and 14 touchdowns through the air. 
Hornets receivers Mitchell Foote and Kavaski Ervin rank second and fourth in the conference in receptions. Foote has 22 receptions for 251 yards while Ervin has 20 for 268 yards. 
Emporia State didn’t miss a beat last week in its first game without injured receiver Justin Brown. 
Receivers Morris Williams II and Anthony Buffalomeat stepped up in Brown’s absence. Williams had four catches for 147 yards and two touchdowns in a 55-14 win against Northeastern State, while Buffalomeat recorded his first career touchdown reception. 
“We knew there we’re going to be some guys who would get their opportunity, and it was good to see those players make the best of that,” Higgins said. MIAA GAMES SATURDAY 
Northwest Missouri at Northeastern State, 1 p.m. 
Missouri Southern at Central Missouri, 1:30 p.m. 
Missouri Western at Pittsburg State, 2 p.m. 
Nebraska-Kearney at Central Oklahoma, 2 p.m. 
Emporia State at Lindenwood, 2:37 p.m. 
Washburn at Fort Hays State, 7 p.m. 
Rick Jr. Peterson can be reached at (785) 295-1290 or rick.peterson.jr@cjonline.com .Follow Rick Jr. on Twitter @RickiePeterson .
